pros: Great staff and management team always friendly and approachable. Everyone is helpful and all staff come together as a team to help those who we support. all patients are friendly and always up for a chat. Great place to work would recommend working here.
cons: No cons absolute great place to work

pros: Fantastic therapists RSW and housekeeping staff
cons: Poor management and leadership coupled with poor collaboration resulting in zero teamwork which makes for a very stressful environment. Has values in place but these are just a corporate exercise and are not applied when it comes to the staff who run this service. Power hungry individuals who would step over you to get what they want. Unrealistic expectations of duties that are not aligned with role. Supervision is not conducive - nothing followed through and any concerns that are raised are quickly dismissed or ignored which in turn causes negative behaviour/attitudes from others.

job_title: Support Worker in Haywards Heath, England

cons: Alot of travel involved in this role

pros: No blame culture, senior management very supportive. Great place to work.
cons: As with all social care, recruitment is constantly a challenge but the organisation put lots of resources into the issue.

pros: Great place, great people, would recommend!
cons: I can't think of any cons.

pros: Great benefits and nice team
cons: Sometimes long hours and difficult shifts

pros: The workload was too much,management don’t care
cons: Don’t do it work is stressful

Never worked at such a backstabbing place, loved the job it was the management team and certain support workers wanting to climb the ladder i couldn't stand. 
They don't like people with a voice and are willing to use it, they just like yes people and unfortunately im not one of them.
Think very careful before going to work here it says rehabilitation well its not anymore its 1-1 people with dementia.

job_title: Area Manager in Bognor Regis, West Sussex, South East England, England
pros: Flexible working, supportive management, great colleagues, lots of training
cons: Nothing that would make a difference

pros: Service users loosing the best staff
cons: Bullying at its best by SLT

review_title: Good services, but a toxic and morally bankrupt management. Avoid at all costs.
job_title: Communications Manager in Burgess Hill, England
pros: The services the charity provides to people with a range of disabilities are generally excellent. There are also some really good, committed people working here.
cons: There is a culture of bullying and picking people off one-by-one by senior management, supported by HR. Supposed ‘restructuring’ and fabricated allegations are used to push people out and staff turnover is huge. In the six months I was there, I had 3 managers, with my last boss resigning before I could! With no explanation, the workforce has been silently reduced by over 450 people in the last 3 years. There is no transparency whatsoever, neither is it clear what the company strategy is or what progress is being made. The good people leave, or are forced out, while the toxic minority rule the roost. A weak CEO who you rarely hear from, is easily manipulated and does nothing to try and change the culture. A regressive office working culture was also introduced while I was there: Strict 9-5pm, with no home working without good reason - simply archaic, distrusting of staff and unnecessary.

pros: Excellent company to work for
cons: There are no cons that all other organisations do not experience, The DT Group are a fantastic organisation to work for.

review_title: Hugely rewarding - an opportunity to make a real difference
job_title: Project Development Manager in Burgess Hill, England
pros:
Worked at HQ for 2 years. Empowering managers provided right conditions for me to thrive, be creative in approaches and development of projects, to take ownership, lots of scope to broaden my role. I’m moving on soon but have found it an immense privilege to play a part in making a difference to those with unmet needs. My team spread around the UK, Burgess Hill and Wakefield were (are!) amazing, hardworking, close-knit, innovative and always striving for excellence. The ability to work flexibly within reason was a big plus. The office vibe is friendly and approachable with good camaraderie. 
In the service units, the vast majority of managers and staff put their all into making their service users lives happy and fulfilling. Clinical, CEO and Senior Management are passionate, driven, approachable and forward looking to continually improve conditions around the Trust for staff and service users.
cons: Being a charity can be difficult to match benefits to that which larger corporates can offer but they’re trying hard to balance this with front line needs. IT has been glitchy of late but improving as they upgrade, modernise and streamline equipment & systems.

pros: Great values and good employer
cons: Nothing to report that I can think of.

pros: It’s a good place to work.
cons: Sometimes can be hard work with people with disabilities

review_title: Loved my time at the Trust
pros:
I worked for the Trust for just under two years, and overall I have enjoyed all of my time here. I’ve had wonderful colleagues and developed great relationships with the wider Trust.

Like any job, there are ups and downs that come with working in a pressured environment where there are real repercussions if you do not work to a high standard, as it should be.

The Trust is not an organisation to join if you are not going to commit to your role fully, but if you do and you show that you are competent and knowledgeable, you will become a trusted member of the organisation and be recognised for your contribution from Directors, Senior Managers and Junior Managers.

If you want an easy job where you won't be held accountable, then this isn't the place for you.
cons: Some salaries aren't quite as competitive as the private sector but the Trust have recently improved their Benefits and increased annual leave across the entire organisation as well as other softer benefits.

review_title: Could be a lot better place
pros: Rewarding work giving good job satisfaction when a service user does well.
cons: Management  can be very negative towards staff, a lot of criticism and very rare praise given which makes it a hard place to be happy working. Sometimes there is a degree of unkind  treatment from some staff towards other staff members.

review_title: Great management and opportunities to develop
pros:
My role at the Disabilities Trust sees me busier than ever, but the hard work is rewarded and recognised by supportive, engaged management who want to make a difference to the people the charity supports. I feel encouraged to develop my skills and grow within my role, and every day is different. This is a huge motivational factor which gives me great job satisfaction.

The opportunities to work flexibly where possible are greatly appreciated, and encourage me to go the extra mile whenever I can.
cons: Change can be slow to implement, but unlike so many other organisations, the Trust listen to their staff, and the organisation is heading in great places, which I'm excited to be a part of.

job_title: in Crawley, West Sussex, South East England, England
pros: Job security, firm but fair. Staff work hard.
cons:
Antiquated management practices, beuracratic, red tape galore. Being regulated by the CQC definitely brings its challenges, however, they would benefit from looking outside at how other health centres operate, more efficiently and effectively - ultimately saving money for the charity by adapting management practices.

Staff are expected to be all things to all people at the same time, the paperwork is immense. No reward, just high expectations; unrealistic unbalanced expectations that staff will automatically be willing to constantly and unreasonably go above just beyond because they work for a charity.

pros: Ideas are shared at all levels. There is an open door policy. The Ethics of the employees as well as the company as a whole mean you can make a positive difference to vulnerable people's lives whatever role you have. I love working here and the staff are incredibly dedicated and passionate.
cons: It's a charity so the salaries and perks might not be able to match a for profit company. The rewards are in the work itself.

review_title: It could have been a great place to work.
pros: They have such a high staff turnover it's possible to progress quickly.
cons:
The Directors took an interest (via survey) in our ideas and suggestions of how we could make it a great place to work. There were some very clear themes and some of the ideas were free e.g dress down Friday. Unfortunately, the efforts of the respondents went to waste and the Directors decided that they wouldn’t pursue the ideas any further. This was very deflating for the office staff who made very good suggestions.

Staff engagement was terrible and it was met with awkwardness from the Senior Management.

Although some of the colleagues were very efficient and capable there seemed to be a culture where they did not feel empowered to make common sense decisions and followed the computer says no mentality which is reflection of the management.

pros: The people and staff in the homes are a delight, even with the constraints of head office you do feel you are making a slight difference to lives.
cons: Paperwork based, takes you away from the care, managers under pressure from company. Low pay and lots of promises to get you to work longer hours.

job_title: Area Manager in Bognor Regis, West Sussex, South East England, England
pros: Excellent training, great hours, pension,  health care and annual leave
cons: This job is what I expected, the only downside is the on call rota

job_title: IT Senior Specialist in Burgess Hill, England
pros: The vision was and still is a good thing. Be true to that.
cons:
The CEO is Ex-Corporate Finance and has driven the organisation into financial turmoil with a string of bad decisions. Taking the Trust from a strong position to one in dire straights. 

Too many chiefs, not enough Indians - middle management and SMT outnumber those actually keeping the business online and operational. 

Disproportionate bonus scheme for the SMT - disgusting for a “national charity”

None competitive Salaries

pros: How can anyone name these
cons: Cutbacks affecting lower level staff

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Burgess Hill, England
pros: The most important thing is the welfare of the service users.  What is done for them and the research being done to improve their life is amazing.
cons: Work hard and expected to work after hours with no overtime paid. Morale is very low. No benefits. Start on 21 days holiday. Pension is auto enrol. Staff pay for own Christmas meal. Allow flexible working but only agree occasionally.

job_title: Residential Support Worker in Nottingham, England
pros: Lovely team work with other support workers
cons: Terrible unqualified and unprofessional management, they are like a gang that team up on any staff that raises questions, they dont listen to their staff and dont support their staff in anyway.  A lot of the people in management at the DT shouldn't be there in the first place, typical case of the blind leading the blind.

review_title: Care more about money that keeping clients safe
pros: Minimal staff stick that to the mission statement, ability to do an NVQ. The clients.
cons: Clients are neglected, staff should be checking regularly but refuse to and the management couldn't care less as long as they get the money out of them. Leaving was the best decision I ever made. Whistleblowing policy is a joke.

pros: None except for the lovely service users. The views are nice for the service users also. Nice food and kitchen staff :)
cons: Working at Victoria house was a nightmare!!! Management are a joke. Made all the staff miserable and not part of a team. The management are unreliable and unapproachable. Only good point is the service users. I highly advise do not get a job there!!!

pros: Very rewarding day-to-day work alongside an excellent core staff team. Good quality training provided as well as better-than-average employment benefits for the sector.
cons: Upper levels of management are bogged down in beurocracy.

pros: Some good people working there who really care
cons: Senior management are bullies, blame culture, unwilling to take risks, hierarchical, no scope to make any progress.
